awd_titl_txt: Single Molecule Studies of Protein Folding
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental obstacle to understanding the rules of Life, is the lack of a predictive, molecular understanding of the mechanisms by which the genome encodes the function of a protein. This project will provide biophysical information on how the amino acid sequence and the environment tune a protein's energy landscape, the mapping between protein structure or conformation and thermodynamic properties which govern its stability. This connection between amino acid sequence, environment and energy landscape is imperative for the ability to design proteins with targeted behaviors such as function, mechanical properties, and lifetime. In addition, the PI will develop a program to provide broad career exposure, exploration and experience to graduate students and postdocs in the life sciences at UC Berkeley.  A novel Professionals in Residence (PIR) program will be instituted, where professionals from diverse fields (Industry and Entrepreneurship, Education and Outreach, Policy and Communication, Academic and Research Institutes) will spend several days a year at UC Berkeley interacting with both trainees and faculty - exposing them to successful professionals from a variety of career paths.

The scientific objective of this research is to investigate the protein-folding problem using single molecule mechanical studies and hydrogen exchange techniques. The results from this work will further our understanding of protein folding, the mechanism by which the amino acid sequence directs the energy landscape of a protein (the structures, energies, and rates of interconversion of all of the accessible conformations), a major challenge for modern molecular biology. Without a better understanding of how these features are encoded in a protein sequence, the expanding sequence databases continue to conceal the answers to many important questions. The results of the single-molecule protein folding studies will yield observables that can be used directly in theoretical studies of protein folding and the experiments will be carried out in an iterative collaboration with theoreticians in the field. Mechanical stress plays a ubiquitous role in protein function and biology, and therefore, in addition to providing needed insight into the protein-folding problem, this work will also provide much needed information about the mechanical stability of proteins.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

por.por_cntn:
An organism's DNA encodes the sequences for all of its individual proteins, which encodes the information for proteins to fold and function, ultimately determining the overall behavior (phenotype) of the organism. A fundamental obstacle in our ability predict phenotype is our lack of a predictive, molecular understanding of this process and the effects of sequence variation.  Today, thanks to advances in machine learning, genomic data bases, and the large number of known structures, we have the ability to accurately predict a structural model for the folded (functional) state of a protein given only its amino-acid sequence.  However, the sequence of a protein encodes more than just this native structure ? it encodes the entire energy landscape ? an ensemble of conformations whose energetics and dynamics are finely tuned. Therefore, proteins should not be thought of as single static structures, but as statistical ensembles.  Modulations of this ensemble or landscape plays a crucial role in many cellular and molecular processes, including the process of protein folding, ligand binding, protein turnover, signaling, and function. Modulations of the landscape also lead to pathologies associated with misfolding. The work accomplished on this project involved investigating a protein's landscape using biophysical approaches that allow one to observe single protein molecules and very rare and transient structures (conformations). 

 

During the project period, we developed and used several methods that involve using an optical trap (laser tweezers) to observe the different conformations that a single protein molecule samples under a given set of conditions.  One approach we developed, termed chemo-mechanical unfolding, allowed us to discover multiple unfolding pathways for a protein.  These pathways have structurally different transition states, and small changes in the protein sequence and environment strongly modulate which path a protein takes, suggesting that different environments within a cell could strongly influence the mechanism of protein folding. We also used our optical trap approach, in combination with computer simulations, to probe the process of misfolding, identifying a rare (or ?hidden?) partially-folded structure of a small protein domain and showed that this hidden state is involved in its misfolding. Finally, in an effort to develop methods to improve the noise and sensitivity of such optical trap experiments we investigated the limits and benefits of replacing dsDNA linker with rigid DNA nanotubes.  We found that DNA nanotubes are only advantageous when studying folding events of small biomolecules which occur in the sub-millisecond time scale.

 

In March 2020, we, like many other labs, redirected some of our research effort to COVID-related work. Using a technique called hydrogen-deuterium exchange monitored by mass spectrometry we discovered a new conformation of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein ? an open trimer that interconverts slowly with the canonical prefusion structure solved by cryoEM. The relative population of each conformation is temperature-dependent, with the open trimer being the dominant species in lower temperatures.  This open trimer exposes unique regions of the protein for antibody binding ? these regions are the most conserved part of the protein and provide sites for potential pan-coronavirus antibody/ligand recognition. Knowledge of the structure and population of this conformation will be important in the design of improved diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines. Since many biochemical and diagnostic assays use these isolated spike constructs, he temperature and time-dependent changes in populations complicates quantitative analysis of binding affinities.

 

Intellectual merit: The results from these studies further our understanding of the mechanism by which the amino acid sequence directs the energy landscape of a protein, which is a major challenge for molecular biology. Without a better understanding of how these features are encoded in a protein sequence, the expanding sequence databases continue to conceal the answers to many important questions. The project provided biophysical information on how both sequence and environment tune the landscape and developed new methods to study using an optical trap and mass spectrometry, identifying alternative conformations of proteins not seen using standard structural tools.

 

Broader Impact:

Research: The results provide a deeper understanding of the relationship between a proteins sequence and energy landscape, an important and missing link in our interpretation of a protein?s sequence. The newly discovered open trimer of the spike protein will be important in the design of improved therapeutics, and vaccines.

Outreach and education: The PI developed a campus-wide program provide broad career exposure, exploration and experience to graduate students and postdocs in the life sciences at UC Berkeley. Funds from this project were used to institute a novel Professionals in Residence (PIR) program where professionals from diverse fields (Industry and Entrepreneurship, Education and Outreach, Policy and Communication, Academic and Research Institutes) spent a day interacting with trainees at UC Berkeley.  This program benefited both trainees and faculty by exposing them to professionals from a variety of career paths. The PI also initiated a post-doctoral affairs office serving all (~300) post-doctoral fellows in her department.
